examples: It's not his fault he's so pompous—he was born that way.

idioms.text: be (all) downhill | be downhill all the way (informal)
idioms.sense: to be easy compared with what came beforeto become worse or less successful
examples: It's all downhill from here. We'll soon be finished.
It's been all downhill for his career since then, with four defeats in five games.
I started work as a journalist and it was downhill all the way for my health.

idioms.text: be downhill all the way | be (all) downhill (informal)
idioms.sense: to be easy compared with what came beforeto become worse or less successful
examples: It's downhill all the way from here. We'll soon be finished.
I started work as a journalist and it was downhill all the way for my health.
It's been all downhill for his career since then, with four defeats in five games.

idioms.sense: to have habits or opinions that you have had for a long time and that you do not want to change
examples: Grandma is so set in her ways.

idioms.text: be well on the way to something/doing something
idioms.sense: to have nearly achieved something and be going to achieve it soon
examples: She is well on the way to recovery.
He is well on the way to establishing himself among the top ten players in the world.

idioms.sense: by a great amount
examples: He was the best by a long way.

idioms.text: by the way (also by the by/bye)
idioms.sense: used to introduce a comment or question that is not directly related to what you have been talking about
examples: By the way, I found that book you were looking for.
What's the time, by the way?
Oh by the way, if you see Jackie, tell her I'll call her this evening.

idioms.sense: by a route that includes the place mentioned
examples: The artist recently arrived in Paris from Bulgaria by way of Vienna.
She came to TV by way of drama school.

idioms.text: by way of/in the way of something
idioms.sense: as a form of something; for something; as a means of something
examples: He received £600 by way of compensation from the company.
She rolled her eyes by way of an answer and left.

idioms.sense: to start to live or behave in a different way from before
examples: He was in trouble with the police as a teenager but now he’s completely changed his ways.
Your father is unlikely to change his ways now.

idioms.text: claw your way back, into something, out of something, to something, etc.
idioms.sense: to gradually achieve something or move somewhere by being determined and using a lot of effort
examples: She clawed her way to the top of her profession.
Slowly, he clawed his way out from under the collapsed building.

idioms.text: clear the way (for something/for something to happen)
idioms.sense: to remove things that are stopping the progress or movement of something
examples: The ruling could clear the way for extradition proceedings.

idioms.sense: to happen to you by chance, or when you were not expecting it
examples: He took the first job that came his way.
Have any interesting articles come your way recently?

idioms.sense: to have two opposite effects or results

idioms.text: either way | one way or the other
idioms.sense: used to say that it does not matter which one of two possibilities happens, is chosen or is true
examples: Was it his fault or not? Either way, an explanation is due.
We could meet today or tomorrow—I don't mind one way or the other.

idioms.sense: in all directions
examples: Her hair tumbled every which way.

idioms.sense: to move along carefully, for example when it is dark, by touching walls, objects, etc.to be careful about how you do things, usually because you are in a situation that you are not familiar with
examples: She was new in the job, still feeling her way.

idioms.sense: to discover the right route (to a place)
examples: I hope you can find your way home.

idioms.sense: to come to a place or a situation by chance or without intending to
examples: He eventually found his way into acting.

idioms.text: get into/out of the way of (doing) something
idioms.sense: to become used to doing something/to lose the habit of doing something
examples: The women had got into the way of going up on the deck every evening.

idioms.sense: to prevent somebody from doing something; to prevent something from happening
examples: He wouldn't allow emotions to get in the way of him doing his job.

idioms.sense: to get or do what you want, especially when somebody has tried to stop you
examples: She always gets her own way in the end.

idioms.sense: to break or fall down
examples: The pillars gave way and a section of the roof collapsed.
Her numb leg gave way beneath her and she stumbled clumsily.

idioms.sense: to stop resisting somebody/something; to agree to do something that you do not want to doto allow somebody/something to be or go first
examples: He refused to give way on any of the points.
Give way to traffic already on the roundabout.

idioms.sense: to allow yourself to be very strongly affected by something, especially an emotionto be replaced by something
examples: Flinging herself on the bed, she gave way to helpless misery.
The storm gave way to bright sunshine.
As he drew nearer, his anxiety gave way to relief.

idioms.sense: to have full sexual intercourse with somebody
to have known each other for a long time
examples: We go back a long way, he and I.

idioms.sense: to last a long time
examples: She seems to make her money go a long way.
A small amount of this paint goes a long way (= covers a large area).
(ironic) I find that a little of Jerry's company can go a long way (= I quickly get tired of being with him).

idioms.text: go a long/some way towards doing something
idioms.sense: to help very much/a little in achieving something
examples: The new law goes a long way towards solving the problem.

idioms.text: go out of your way (to do something)
idioms.sense: to make a special effort to do something
examples: He would always go out of his way to be friendly towards her.
She went out of her way to help them.

idioms.sense: to do as you choose, especially when somebody has advised you against it
examples: It's best to let her go her own way if you don't want a fight.
He's always gone his own way when it comes to design.

idioms.sense: to end a relationship with somebodyto go in a different direction from somebody you have been travelling with
examples: When the business was sold they went their separate ways.
They decided to go their separate ways after being together for five years.
When we finished school, we all went our separate ways.

idioms.sense: to travel in the same direction as somebodyto go well for you; to be in your favour
examples: I'm going your way—I'll walk with you.
I'm going your way, so we can walk together.
She was going my way, so we talked as we walked.
By the third round he knew the fight was going his way.

idioms.text: go the way of all flesh
idioms.sense: to die
by having an unpleasant experience or by making mistakes
examples: She won't listen to my advice so she'll just have to learn the hard way.
He learned about the dangers of drugs the hard way.

idioms.sense: to have made a lot of progress
examples: We've come a long way since the early days of the project.
The study of genes has come a long way in recent years.

idioms.text: have your head screwed on (the right way)
idioms.sense: to be a sensible person
to have or want to have the advantages of two different situations or ways of behaving that are impossible to combine
examples: You can't have it both ways. If you can afford to go out all the time, you can afford to pay off some of your debts.

idioms.sense: used to say in an angry way that although you are not happy about something that somebody has said, you are not going to argue
examples: Oh OK, then. Have it your own way!

idioms.sense: to have something arranged in the way that you want, even though other people want it to be arranged differently
examples: The German team weren't going to let the English have everything their own way.

idioms.text: have a long way to go
idioms.sense: to need to make a lot of progress before you can achieve something
examples: She still has a long way to go before she's fully fit.

idioms.text: have a way of doing something
idioms.sense: used to say that something often happens in a particular way, especially when it is out of your control
examples: First love affairs have a way of not working out.
Fate has a way of changing the best of plans.

idioms.sense: to be good at dealing with somebody/something
examples: He has a way with small children.
She has a way with words (= is very good at expressing herself).

idioms.sense: to persuade somebody to have sex with you
used to explain what you would do if you had total control over something
examples: If I had my way, smoking would be banned completely.

idioms.sense: of any type
examples: I don't approve of violence in any shape or form.
I can't stand insects in any shape or form.
I do not condone bullying in any way, shape or form.

idioms.sense: on a large/small scale
examples: The new delivery service has taken off in a big way.
Many people are investing in a small way in the stock market.
He then started spending money in a big way.

idioms.sense: (to be/become) pregnant
used to show that a statement has more than one meaning
examples: With the first goal he used his head in more ways than one.

idioms.sense: used to say what normally happens in a particular situation
examples: In the ordinary way, she's not a nervous person.

idioms.sense: how and when you want to, even though this might annoy other people
examples: He always does the work, but in his own sweet time.
She just ignores all the criticism and continues on her own sweet way.

idioms.text: in a way | in one way | in some ways
idioms.sense: to some extent; not completely
examples: In a way it was one of our biggest mistakes.
It's more interesting, in some ways, to watch what's going on behind the scenes here.
In a certain way, all of that is true.

idioms.text: in her, his, its, etc. (own) way
idioms.sense: in a manner that is appropriate to or typical of a person or thing but that may seem unusual to other people
examples: I expect she does love you in her own way.
The building is very attractive in its own way.
He was attractive in his own way.

idioms.sense: stopping somebody from moving or doing something
examples: You'll have to move—you're in my way.
I left them alone, as I felt I was in the way.
There were several rocks in the way.

idioms.sense: used in questions and negative sentences to talk about the types of something that are available
examples: There isn't much in the way of entertainment in this place.

idioms.sense: to avoid somebody
examples: Let's keep out of her way while she's in such a bad mood.

idioms.sense: to be familiar with a place, subject, etc.

idioms.text: laugh all the way to the bank
idioms.sense: to make a lot of money easily and feel very pleased about it

idioms.text: lie your way into/out of something
idioms.sense: to get yourself into or out of a situation by lying
to deliberately avoid seeing somebody/something
examples: Prison officers know what's going on, but look the other way.

idioms.sense: to become lostto forget or move away from the purpose or reason for something
examples: We lost our way in the dark.
She lost her way in the fog.
I feel that the project has lost its way.
This project seems to have lost its way.

idioms.sense: to allow somebody/something to pass; to allow somebody/something to take the place of somebody/something
examples: Make way for the Lord Mayor!
Tropical forest is felled to make way for grassland.

idioms.sense: to move or get somewhere; to make progress
examples: Will you be able to make your own way to the airport (= get there without help, a ride, etc.)?
Is this your plan for making your way in the world?

idioms.sense: to stop behaving badly

idioms.text: (steer, take, etc.) a middle course | (find, etc.) a/the middle way
idioms.sense: (to take/find) an acceptable course of action that avoids two extreme positions

idioms.text: (there are) no two ways about it
idioms.sense: used to show that you are certain about something
examples: It was the wrong decision—there are no two ways about it.

idioms.sense: used to say that there is no possibility that you will do something or that something will happen
examples: ‘Do you want to help?’ ‘No way!’
No way am I going to drive them there.
There's no way we could afford that sort of money.

idioms.sense: during the journeygoing or comingnot yet born
examples: He stopped for breakfast on the way.
She grabbed her camera and bag on her way out.
We didn't stop on the way north.
They bought some supplies on the way.
We stopped for a drink on the way home.
On the way back, he invited me to his home for drinks.
I'd better be on my way (= I must leave) soon.
The letter should be on its way to you.
Then he went off on his merry way.
They've got three kids and one on the way.

idioms.text: open the way for somebody/something (to do something)
idioms.sense: to make it possible for somebody to do something or for something to happen
examples: The agreement could open the way for the country to pay off its debts.

idioms.sense: in the opposite position, direction or orderthe opposite situation
examples: I think it should go on the other way round.
I didn't leave you. It was the other way round (= you left me).

idioms.sense: in a safe place where somebody/something cannot be hurt or injured or do any damage to somebody/something
examples: She put the knife in a drawer, out of harm’s way.
I prefer the children to play in the garden where they’re out of harm’s way.

idioms.sense: no longer stopping somebody from moving or doing somethingfinished; dealt withused in negative sentences to mean ‘unusual’
examples: I moved my legs out of the way so that she could get past.
I didn't say anything until Dad was out of the way.
Our region is poised for growth once the election is out of the way.
She had obviously noticed nothing out of the way.

idioms.sense: not on the route that you planned to take
examples: I'd love a ride home—if it's not out of your way.
The supermarket is a bit out of my way.
The library is slightly out of my way.

idioms.sense: a point at which two people or groups of people decide to separate
examples: These events led to a final parting of the ways.

idioms.sense: to create a situation in which somebody will be able to do something or something can happen
examples: This decision paved the way for changes in employment rights for women.

idioms.sense: to make enough money to pay what it costs to keep it going
examples: The bridge is still not paying its way.

idioms.sense: to pay for everything yourself without having to rely on anyone else’s money

idioms.text: pick your way (across, along, among, over, through something)
idioms.sense: to walk carefully, choosing the safest, driest, etc. place to put your feet
examples: She picked her way delicately over the rough ground.
We picked our way carefully over the jagged rocks.

idioms.text: rub somebody up the wrong way (British English) (North American English rub somebody the wrong way)
idioms.sense: to make somebody annoyed or angry, often without intending to, by doing or saying something that offends them
examples: She tends to rub people up the wrong way.

idioms.text: see, realize, etc. the error of your ways
idioms.sense: to realize or admit that you have done something wrong and decide to change your behaviour
examples: Will they realize the error of their ways before it is too late?

idioms.text: see your way (clear) to doing something/to do something
idioms.sense: to find that it is possible or convenient to do something
examples: Small builders cannot see their way clear to take on many trainees.

idioms.text: see which way the wind is blowing
idioms.sense: to get an idea of what is likely to happen before deciding what to do
to do something first so that other people can follow
to make it easier for somebody/something to develop or make progress
examples: These negotiations are intended to smooth the path to a peace treaty.
We’re trying to smooth the way for women who want to resume their careers.

idioms.sense: to (not) prevent somebody from doing something
examples: If you believe you can make her happy, I won't stand in your way.
He wanted to go to college and would let nothing stand in his way.

idioms.sense: to be bisexual (= sexually attracted to both men and women)
to end a difficult situation by choosing the simplest solution even if it is not the best one
examples: He took the easy way out and didn’t go to the meeting.
She took the easy way out and paid someone to write the article for her.

idioms.sense: to be offended by a remark that was not intended to be offensive
examples: She always takes things the wrong way.

idioms.text: talk your way out of something/of doing something
idioms.sense: to make excuses and give reasons for not doing something; to manage to get yourself out of a difficult situation
examples: I managed to talk my way out of having to give a speech.

idioms.text: that’s the way the cookie crumbles
idioms.sense: that is the situation and we cannot change it, so we must accept it

idioms.text: there’s more than one way to skin a cat
idioms.sense: there are many different ways to achieve something
in my opinion
having started
examples: Preparations are well under way for a week of special events in May.

idioms.sense: a plan of action that is likely to be successful
examples: Personal electronic health records are the way forward for effective healthcare in the future.

idioms.text: a way into something (also a way in to something)
idioms.sense: something that allows you to join a group of people, an industry, etc. that it is difficult to join, or to understand something that it is difficult to understand
the typical pattern of behaviour of a person or group
examples: the American way of life
She loved the Spanish way of life and immediately felt at home there.
the beliefs and practices of the Hindu way of life

idioms.sense: the way that most people behave; the way that things happen, which you cannot change
examples: The rich and powerful make the decisions—that's the way of the world.

idioms.sense: used to say that somebody else has either to agree with your opinion or to leave
the methods and materials available for doing something
examples: ways and means of raising money
Newspapers have ways and means of getting hold of secret information.

idioms.sense: used to tell somebody that you are pleased about something they have done
examples: Good work, guys! Way to go!
Way to go! I wish I could do that!

idioms.sense: the way to make somebody like or love you
examples: The way to a man's heart is through his stomach (= by giving him good food).

idioms.text: where there’s a will there’s a way
idioms.sense: if you really want to do something then you will find a way of doing it
a series of victories or successes
examples: He'll look to continue his winning ways with a victory in Mexico on 16 February.

idioms.sense: to do something from beginning to end, especially when it takes a lot of time or effort
examples: She worked her way through the pile of documents.

idioms.text: work your way through college, round the world, etc.
idioms.sense: to have a job or series of jobs while studying, travelling, etc. in order to pay for your education, etc.
to move regularly to a more senior position in a company
examples: He worked his way up from messenger boy to account executive.
